context.definition: Textile is the field concerned with the design, production, properties, and applications of fibres, yarns, fabrics, and textile-based products.
context.role: Provides the structural foundation for understanding all textile materials, processes, and applications.

context.definition: Fibres are the fundamental raw materials of textiles, characterized by high length-to-diameter ratio and flexibility.
context.role: All textile structures originate from fibres; their properties strongly influence yarn, fabric, and end-use performance.

context.definition: Natural fibres are obtained from plant, animal, or mineral sources and are biodegradable in nature.
context.role: They form the earliest and most widely used class of textile fibres.

context.definition: Plant fibres are cellulosic fibres derived from various parts of plants such as seeds, stems, leaves, and fruits.
Cellulosic fibres are composed mainly of cellulose, a natural polymer responsible for strength, absorbency, and biodegradability.
This section explains the structure of cotton fibres and plant anatomy influencing fibre properties.
Bast fibres are obtained from the stem or phloem of plants such as hemp, jute, and flax.
Leaf fibres are extracted from the leaves of plants like sisal and banana and are known for their stiffness and strength.
Fruit fibres are obtained from fruits, with coir extracted from coconut husk being the most common example.
Animal fibres are protein-based fibres obtained from animal hair, fur, or secretions.
Fibres obtained from animal hair such as sheep wool, goat hair, and camel hair.
A natural protein fibre produced by spiders, known for exceptional strength and elasticity.
Silkworm silk is a natural filament protein fibre produced by silkworms, prized for its smoothness, luster, strength, and fine handle.
context.role: It is the most commercially important form of natural silk and plays a central role in apparel, luxury textiles, and emerging biomedical applications.

context.definition: This section introduces silk as a natural protein fibre and covers sericulture, the scientific practice of rearing silkworms for silk production.
context.role: Provides foundational understanding of silk origin, lifecycle of silkworms, and primary production stages.

context.definition: Silk can be classified based on silkworm species and geographical origin, including mulberry, tasar, eri, and muga silk.
context.role: Helps distinguish silk varieties based on fibre structure, luster, fineness, and end-use applications.

references.title: Central Silk Board – Types of Silk

context.definition: Post-cocoon technology includes processes such as reeling, throwing, degumming, and dyeing of silk fibres after cocoon formation.
context.role: Transforms raw silk into usable yarns and fabrics while controlling quality and performance characteristics.

context.definition: This section explains the molecular structure of silk fibroin and sericin and their influence on mechanical, thermal, and aesthetic properties.
context.role: Links fibre structure to performance characteristics such as strength, elasticity, luster, and moisture regain.

books.title: Physical Properties of Textile Fibres
books.author: W. E. Morton and J. W. S. Hearle

context.definition: Silk is used in apparel, medical sutures, biomedical textiles, home furnishings, and high-value luxury products.
context.role: Demonstrates the versatility of silk in both traditional and advanced technical applications.

context.definition: Mineral fibres are inorganic fibres obtained from naturally occurring minerals.
Regenerated fibres are man-made fibres produced from natural polymers through chemical processing.
context.role: They bridge the gap between natural and synthetic fibres.

context.definition: These fibres include inorganic and high-performance fibres designed for specialised applications.
Yarn formation involves converting fibres into continuous strands through various spinning and bonding processes.
context.role: Acts as the intermediate stage linking fibres to fabric structures.

context.definition: Fabric formation refers to processes that convert yarns or fibres into planar textile structures.
context.role: Determines the structural geometry and mechanical behavior of textile products.

context.definition: Wet processing includes chemical and mechanical treatments such as scouring, bleaching, dyeing, printing, and finishing.
context.role: Enhances appearance, functionality, and end-use performance of textile materials.

context.definition: Textile properties describe the mechanical, physical, thermal, and comfort-related behavior of fibres, yarns, and fabrics.
context.role: Used to evaluate performance, quality, and suitability for specific applications.

context.definition: Technical textiles are textile products engineered primarily for performance and functional properties rather than aesthetics.
context.role: Represents high-value, application-driven segments of the textile industry.

context.definition: Textiles used in agriculture, horticulture, and fisheries to enhance crop productivity and protect plants.
context.role: Improves yield, reduces environmental stress, and supports sustainable farming.

context.definition: Textiles used in medical and healthcare applications such as implants, wound care, and hygiene products.
context.role: Supports healthcare delivery, infection control, and patient safety.

context.definition: Textiles used in civil engineering and construction for soil stabilization and erosion control.
context.role: Enhances infrastructure durability and environmental protection.

context.definition: Textiles used in construction such as roofing membranes, insulation, and architectural fabrics.
context.role: Improves energy efficiency, safety, and structural performance.

context.definition: Textiles used in transportation including automobiles, aerospace, railways, and marine applications.
context.role: Reduces weight, increases safety, and improves comfort.

context.definition: Protective textiles used for personal and industrial safety.
context.role: Protects against fire, chemicals, mechanical, and biological hazards.

context.definition: Textiles used in packaging for industrial, agricultural, and consumer goods.
context.role: Ensures safe handling, storage, and transport of products.

context.definition: Textiles used in sports and leisure applications.
context.role: Enhances performance, comfort, and safety.

context.definition: Textile machinery includes equipment used in fibre processing, spinning, fabric formation, and finishing.
context.role: Controls productivity, quality, and efficiency in textile manufacturing.

context.definition: This area deals with production planning, quality management, supply chain, and economics of textile industries.
context.role: Connects technical textile knowledge with industrial decision-making.

context.definition: Focuses on environmentally responsible textile production and intelligent textile systems.
context.role: Represents the future direction of textile research and innovation.
